title: From Making A Murderer to missing Madeleine McCann: How true crime shows affect locals
text:
Fred and Rose West killed at least 12 people (Picture: SWNS)

The world has been gripped by true crime stories for years, with countless documentaries, chatrooms and podcasts dedicated to retracing the exact timeline of some of the biggest cases.

Sky’s new Sky Crime channel recently launched to help quench the thirst, exploring the cases of Serial’s Adnan Syed and Garrett Phillips, among many more.

But, while we are all desperate for new information, we can sometimes be guilty of forgetting about those directly affected by each case, with local residents having their entire world turned upside down by horrors happening on their doorstep.

And, in some cases, they are still desperately trying to recover their anonymity.

Making A Murderer’s Steven Avery: Manitowoc, United States

One particular case is that of Steven Avery, who is currently serving a life sentence for the first-degree murder of Teresa Halbach, who was killed in 2005.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Popular Netflix series Making A Murderer shone a light on his case, and his town of Manitowoc, Wisconsin, long after he was originally jailed, with viewers speculating whether he has been framed for the crime.

However, with millions of people tuning into the first two seasons of the true-crime documentary, residents of Manitowoc have been left ‘frustrated’, desperate to move on with their lives.

‘We all thought it was over with, the past,’ town Chairman Ed Peterik told Green Bay Press Gazette. ‘Sometimes it just gets a little overwhelming with people wanting to not let it go.’

Steven Avery is serving a life sentence for Teresa Halbach’s murder (Picture: Getty)

While residents are tired of hearing about the Avery case, as well as the show.

Bar owner Stacey Vanderbloomen recently told the Mirror: ‘It’s like trying to keep religion and politics out of the bar.

‘I tell them let’s not talk about it anymore.’

The documentary has attracted ‘dark tourists’ to Manitowoc, with those wanting to see the area with their very own eyes, instead of through their Netflix account.

But, despite bringing in money to local restaurants, residents would rather they left.

‘It’ll bring people who are going to eat and spend money, but that’s not the type of money we really want,’ a regular pub-goer added.

Fred and Rose West’s House of Horrors: Gloucester, United Kingdom

As well as TV crews, the crimes themselves shed an unwanted light on a local area. One of the most infamous true crime cases is that of Fred and Rose West. Shockwaves were sent around the country in 1994, after it emerged they raped and murdered several young women – including their own daughters.

Advertisement

Advertisement

It was later revealed they sexually assaulted, murdered and dismembered at least 12 people, with nine bodies later found on their property at 25 Cromwell Street, in Gloucester – which was later dubbed the ‘house of horrors’.

And Canon Adrian Slade, from the Diocese of Gloucester, explained the city was ‘deeply traumatised’ when their crimes came to light.

They buried people in their ‘house of horrors’ on Cromwell Street (Picture: Rex)

Speaking about how the case changed the area, he explained: ‘There was a lot of grief, a lot of feeling of we should have known. And I think a lot of people were anxious that what happened with Fred West and Rosemary was something they should have been on top of.

‘And I think that feeling of grief and anger and sadness penetrated into the whole city. I think the city was deeply traumatised.’

Despite occurring 25 years ago, he explained that some people who live there still identify themselves by the ordeal.

‘And I think when you talk to people in Gloucester they still self-identify as a city where the West case occurred,’ he told BBC. ‘I think Gloucester went through a period of mourning. And I think it’s got through it. I think it’s come out the other side.’

Disappearance of Madeleine McCann: Praia da Luz, Portugal

Madeleine McCann disappeared in 2007 (Picture: PA)

The world came to a standstill when Madeleine McCann disappeared from the bedroom of her family’s holiday apartment, on 3 May 2007, in Praia da Luz.

For months afterwards, pictures of the Portuguese town were splashed on front pages and rolling news channels, as the search grew for the three-year-old, who is still missing to this day.

Advertisement

And, 12 years after that fateful night, Praia da Luz locals are still struggling to come to terms with what happened – especially following a recent Netflix documentary about the ordeal.

A local cafe worker explained that even now people often come and ask for more information on exactly where Maddie went missing.

‘We do get a lot of people asking, “Where is the place that Maddie disappeared?” We have to show them on maps a lot of times,’ Jessica Geislinger admitted.

Praia da Luz has never been the same since her disappearance (Picture: PA)

While fellow local Ana Faria said: ‘That summer was totally rubbish and then the following seasons were also very weak and nobody can do anything about it.

‘We have to pay the price for somebody else’s problems.’

However, despite a ‘massive drop’ in the number of tourists visiting Praia da Luz since Maddie’s disappearance, a holidaymaker told the publication that the ordeal hasn’t ‘deterred’ him from coming back.

‘We’ve been coming here every year regardless,’ he said. ‘We love it here. It’s still not deterred us. It’s a great little resort.

‘It seems to be getting back to what it was now but I don’t think it will fully ever get back to the amount of tourism it had before, simply because some families still choose not to come here.’

Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman deaths: Soham, United Kingdom

Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman were killed in Soham in 2002 (Picture: PA)

Soham, a small town in Cambridgeshire, was cast under a huge spotlight in 2002, after 10-year-old girls Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman disappeared, after popping out to by sweets during a barbecue.

Advertisement

Their bodies were found in a ditch near Suffolk two weeks later, as it emerged school caretaker Ian Huntley had killed them in his home, with girlfriend Maxine Carr providing a false alibi for him.

And Pauline Williamson, who was close to Holly’s grandmother, explained those living in the area have ‘never forgotten’ their crimes.

Speaking to The Sun, she said: ‘Oh she was a little beauty. Holly was our carnival queen, so whenever it’s carnival you can’t help but think of her. We will never forget, ever. We can’t. It’s always there.

Ian Huntley was found guilty of their murders (Picture: PA)

‘I don’t feel we can ever let go of what happened. You want to, but it changed Soham for ever.’

‘We hadn’t lived here long when it happened, but I can remember all of it. It was awful,’ friend Christine Palmer recalled.

‘The trouble is that Soham is known only for that to people who don’t live here.

‘I’ve even had it on holiday in Spain, when people ask where you’re from. When you say, they immediately reply, “Oh, isn’t that where those girls were murdered?”

‘It’d be nice if Soham became known for something else. But that will come in time.’

Meredith Kercher death: Perugia, Italy

Meredith Kercher died in Perugia, Italy (Picture: PA)

Meredith Kercher’s death is one of the most famous true crime cases in recent years, and had people around the world gripped.

The British student was found murdered in the home she shared with Amanda Knox, in Perugia, Italy, in 2007.

Amanda was found guilty of killing her roommate, and spent four years behind bars, before being acquitted by an Italian appeals court in 2011.

And locals revealed the town ‘changed overnight’ following the court case and subsequent media attention – which was the focus of a recent Netflix documentary.

Amanda Knox was acquitted of her murder (Picture: AFP)

‘It used to be like any other university town. I swear that Perugia changed overnight – this story changed how we all saw our own city,’ a resident told Vice.

‘Only now it’s starting to get itself back together, but for years the town was reduced to being the backdrop to this trial.’

When asked whether the view of Perugia has been ‘distorted’, another said: ‘Well, American students have stopped coming here. For years, we had a wonderful exchange between cultures and generations – that all disappeared.’

A local continued: ‘Absolutely. I remember, for example, that when I moved to the centre, people warned me to not go out alone because they said it would be dangerous. I heard people talk about nightly fights, shootings, drugs – and I think that a lot of that kind of talk is linked to the Kercher case.’

Sky has launched new channel Sky Crime, with documentaries on some of the biggest real-life investigations that have made the news of late. The channel features shows such as I Love You, Now Die, which follows the trial of 17-year-old Michelle Carter, Kemper on Kemper, which details serial killer Edmund Kemper’s first-hand accounts of his killings.

Sky Crime launched at the beginning of the month and is also available on NOW TV.
